18.title: Handler Pattern
18.content: Each handler follows a consistent pattern: . | Construction â€” Accepts base interface references (not owned) | Lazy initialization â€” Initialize() or EnsureInitialized() creates the CRTP driver | Thread safety â€” RtosMutex protects all public methods | Error propagation â€” Maps driver errors to interface error codes | Zero overhead â€” CRTP dispatch means no virtual function overhead in the driver layer | .

19.title: Ownership Model
19.content: | 1 2 3 4 5 . | Manager (owns) â†’ Handler (owns) â†’ CRTP Driver Instance â”‚ â””â”€â”€ References (not owned) â†’ BaseI2c/BaseSpi/BaseGpio â”‚ â””â”€â”€ Platform creates â†’ EspI2c/EspSpi/EspGpio . | . Key rule: Handlers do NOT own their communication interfaces. The platform layer (or test setup) must ensure interfaces outlive the handler.

20.title: RTOS Integration
20.content: . | RtosMutex â€” Recursive mutex wrapper (xSemaphoreCreateRecursiveMutex), allows same-thread re-entrant locking (e.g. EnsureInitialized() â†’ Initialize()) | MutexLockGuard â€” Typedef for RtosUniqueLock<RtosMutex>, RAII lock guard | PeriodicTimer â€” Wrapper around FreeRTOS software timers | BaseThread â€” Abstract base for FreeRTOS tasks | OsQueue, OsEventFlags, OsSemaphore â€” Standard RTOS primitives | . All handlers use RtosMutex internally. The MutexLockGuard RAII pattern ensures deadlock-free operation even on early returns.

21.title: Communication Adapters (TMC9660 Example)
21.content: The TMC9660 is the most complex handler due to its multi-subsystem architecture: . | 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 . | Tmc9660Handler â”œâ”€â”€ HalSpiTmc9660Comm (CRTP adapter: BaseSpi â†’ SpiCommInterface) â”‚ â””â”€â”€ Tmc9660CtrlPins (RST, DRV_EN, FAULTN, WAKE) â”œâ”€â”€ SpiDriver (tmc9660::TMC9660<HalSpiTmc9660Comm>) â”œâ”€â”€ Gpio wrappers (GPIO17, GPIO18 â†’ BaseGpio) â”œâ”€â”€ Adc wrapper (multi-channel â†’ BaseAdc) â””â”€â”€ Temperature wrapper (chip temp â†’ BaseTemperature) . | . The visitDriver() template pattern routes calls through a type-erased facade, keeping the public API non-templated while preserving zero-overhead dispatch internally. The withDriver() pattern (used by TLE92466ED and MAX22200) is a simplified variant that acquires the mutex, ensures initialization, and invokes a callable on the driver in a single atomic step.

22.title: Callback Conventions
22.content: Base interfaces use raw function pointers with a void* user_data parameter for hardware-level callbacks. This avoids std::function overhead and heap allocation in ISR-safe and performance-critical paths: . | 1 2 3 4 . | // Typical base interface callback typedef using InterruptCallback = void(*)(BaseGpio* gpio, hf_gpio_interrupt_trigger_t trigger, void* user_data); . | . Handlers pass non-capturing lambdas (which decay to function pointers) and route the user_data back to this: . | 1 2 3 4 5 . | gpio.RegisterInterrupt( [](BaseGpio* /*gpio*/, hf_gpio_interrupt_trigger_t /*trigger*/, void* ctx) { static_cast<MyHandler*>(ctx)->OnInterrupt(); }, this); . | . Interfaces that carry this pattern: BaseGpio, BaseTemperature, BasePio, BasePeriodicTimer, BasePwm, BaseCan, and their ESP32 implementations. Higher-level communication interfaces (BaseBluetooth, BaseWifi, BaseLogger) still use std::function because their callbacks carry richer event data where the void* user-data pattern is not sufficient.

Workflows use reusable workflow definitions from two shared CI tool repositories: . | Repository | Purpose | . | hardfoc/hf-espidf-ci-tools | ESP-IDF build, flash, release workflows | . | hardfoc/hf-general-ci-tools | C++ analysis, linting, documentation workflows | . All reusable workflows are pinned at @main.

57.title: 1. ESP-IDF Build (esp32-examples-build-ci.yml)
57.content: Trigger: Push/PR to main, develop, feature/**, release/** . Pipeline stages: . | Validate â€” Checks app_config.yml structure and validates APP_TYPE entries | Build Matrix â€” generate_matrix.py reads app_config.yml, produces a matrix of {app_type, build_type, idf_version} combinations where ci_enabled: true | Build â€” Each matrix entry runs build_app.sh in a Docker container with ESP-IDF | Lint â€” Runs clang-format/clang-tidy on modified files (excludes submodule dirs) | . Only apps with ci_enabled: true in app_config.yml are included in the matrix. Currently, canopen_utils_test and full_integration_test are disabled because they require specific hardware or network configuration.

58.title: 2. C++ Static Analysis (ci-cpp-analysis.yml)
58.content: Trigger: Push/PR modifying handlers/** or _config/** . Runs Cppcheck with --std=c++20 on the handlers/ directory. Catches common bugs, undefined behavior, and style issues.

59.title: 3. C++ Lint (ci-cpp-lint.yml)
59.content: Trigger: Push/PR modifying handlers/** or _config/** . Runs clang-format (style check) and clang-tidy (static analysis) using the configurations in _config/. Excludes hf-core-drivers/ and hf-core-utils/ submodules from analysis.

60.title: 4. Documentation Link Check (ci-docs-linkcheck.yml)
60.content: Trigger: Push/PR modifying docs/** or README.md . Uses lychee to verify all hyperlinks in documentation are reachable. Configuration in _config/lychee.toml excludes known-flaky URLs (shields.io badges, GNU licenses).

61.title: 5. Documentation Publish (ci-docs-publish.yml)
61.content: Trigger: Push to main (deploy), PR to main (build-only) . Two-stage pipeline: . | Jekyll â€” Builds the docs site using _config/_config.yml (Just the Docs theme) | Doxygen â€” Generates API reference from handler source code, outputs to docs/api/ within the Jekyll site | . Deploys to GitHub Pages on push to main.

62.title: 6. Markdown Lint (ci-markdown-lint.yml)
62.content: Trigger: Push/PR modifying **/*.md . Validates Markdown files against .markdownlint.json rules. Excludes submodule directories (hf-core-drivers/**, hf-core-utils/**).

63.title: 7. YAML Lint (ci-yaml-lint.yml)
63.content: Trigger: Push/PR modifying **/*.yml or **/*.yaml . Validates YAML files against .yamllint rules. Excludes submodule directories.

64.title: 8. Release (release.yml)
64.content: Trigger: Push of a tag matching v* . Creates a GitHub Release with: . | Auto-generated changelog from commits since the last tag | Source archive attached as a release artifact | Release notes template | .
